report_title: Automobile Steering & Suspension Manufacturing in the US Mar 2024
executive_summary: Automobile steering and suspension manufacturers primarily produce and rebuild motor vehicle steering and suspension systems and components, including steering wheels, shock absorbers and struts. The industry struggled through the current period, enduring severe travel restrictions, unfavorable trade conditions and weak economic growth. In particular, the pandemic and climbing interest rates bracketed a brief period of torrid new car sales. Similarly, global supply chain disruptions led to notable profit declines as companies struggled to source materials and pass unexpected costs onto buyers. Overall, revenue plummeted at an expected CAGR of 2.9% to $15.7 through the current period, stagnating in 2024, where profit rebounded to 2.7%. Innovation across the automotive sector has created demand for innovative products to support the development of electric and autonomous vehicles. These products require more complex designs, often resulting in close collaboration between parts and vehicle manufacturers. This trend has helped to shield domestic manufacturers from increasing foreign pressure; even so, imports have satisfied an increasing portion of domestic demand, especially for low-cost, generic parts. Rebounding economic conditions, highlighted by normalizing interest rates, robust consumer confidence and a favorable trade-weighted index, will contribute to the industry's strong growth through the outlook period. Similarly, waning input costs will provide significant stability to supply chains, enabling manufacturers to generate stronger returns. Government spending on public transportation and electric vehicles will also create demand for new vehicles, contributing to elevated demand for related steering and suspension parts. Overall, revenue will rebound at an estimated CAGR of 1.8% to $17.2 billion through the current period.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The pandemic weakened consumer markets, cutting spending on big-ticket items like automobiles and repairs; similarly, poor economic conditions and weak corporate profit constrained demand from businesses purchasing new trucks, company cars and other vehicles, like farming or construction vehicles. Lockdown restrictions also limited travel opportunities, creating less demand for travel and repairs. Governments have since lifted stay-at-home orders, enabling consumers to express pent-up demand for travel, leading to temporarily soaring demand for new and used cars and requiring more steering and suspension parts. Even so, climbing interest rates have threatened automotive supply chains. Many buyers rely on loans to purchase a new vehicle; high rates have deterred borrowing, dampening shifting travel trends.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Manufacturers have grappled with volatile supply chains
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The pandemic and the Russian invasion of Ukraine have led to severe input cost volatility and prolonged global supply chain disruptions. In particular, crude oil and steel prices climbed to near-record levels through the current period before slowly receding in 2023 and 2024. Supply chain disruptions have piled onto poor economic performance, leading to notable profit declines; many companies, especially smaller, independent competitors, struggled to pass costs onto buyers, instead absorbing costs at the detriment of profit growth. Larger companies also struggled to remain profitable in 2021, given the global nature of supply chain disruptions. In general, Russian sanctions have eliminated a major supplier of crude oil alongside ferrous and nonferrous metals, limiting supplier options. Overall, manufacturers have struggled to elevate profit to pre-pandemic levels given economic uncertainty and continued supply chain issues.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The proliferation of electric vehicles encourages upstream innovation
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Electric vehicle innovation has created new opportunities for automobile steering and suspension manufacturers to collaborate with automakers and establish themselves as vital parts of the EV manufacturing supply chain alongside traditional combustion vehicle supply chains. In general, suspension systems have few differences between combustion and electric-powered vehicles; in comparison, EVs have an average curb weight of 20% to 30% greater than vehicles with internal combustion vehicles, requiring more power to steer. These changes have opportunities to partner with EV manufacturers to create lighter, more efficient steering systems. More effective steering systems prevent car crashes, helping manufacturers build stronger buyer relationships.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Manufacturers will rely on the economy's recovery
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The economy will recover from the pandemic and high interest rates through the outlook period, encouraging consumers and businesses to purchase new vehicles, stimulating demand for related suspension and steering equipment. Consumers will also have more funds to travel, leading to more wear and tear on vehicles and creating demand from aftermarkets for parts and repairs. More leisure time may also encourage consumers to take short road trips, furthering demand for repairs. Even so, Kelly Blue Book reports that suspension and steering repairs tend to be more costly than other repairs. Suspension repair can cost between $1,000 and $5,000, while power steering pump replacements cost around $900. These repairs are often less frequent than others but may represent a hurdle moving forward. Recovering supply chains will also improve the outlook for automobile steering and suspension manufacturers. Lower input prices will enable manufacturers to reduce production costs while expanding profitability. Automation will also bolster profit and reduce labor costs.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Manufacturers will face continued pressure from foreign producers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Steering and suspension parts are relatively light and cost-effective to shop overseas, contributing to the industry's robust international trade landscape. Manufacturers in low-cost countries, like China and Mexico, have taken advantage of lax labor and environmental regulations to flood domestic markets with inexpensive parts and equipment. Favorable exchange rates will enable domestic manufacturers to regain some ground from foreign competitors through the outlook period, but lower costs will remain a pervasive threat to the domestic industry. Increased specialization in products that pair with electric and autonomous vehicles will also create more niches for high-tech, custom-built suspension and steering products. This trend will likely support growth in the domestic industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Companies will continue to move production offshore
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While the United States has historically been a major hub for automakers and their upstream suppliers, climbing operational and compliance costs have encouraged automobile manufacturers to open facilities in lower-cost countries, contributing to already elevated import penetration. Specifically, Mexico has become a major automotive sector hub in North America, supplying cars across North and South America. At the same time, companies take advantage of favorable government policies, lower labor costs and fewer manufacturing regulations. Many suppliers, including automobile steering and suspension manufacturers, will increasingly relocate to increase proximity to downstream automakers, enabling them to reap the same benefits as auto producers and cut transportation costs.

industry_definition: The Automobile Steering & Suspension Manufacturing industry primarily produces and rebuilds motor vehicle steering and suspension systems and components, including steering wheels, shock absorbers and struts. The industry does not include the manufacturing of steering, suspension and brake components for heavy trucks or other heavy vehicles.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - World price of steel

Global supply chain disruptions led to volatile input costs and profit declines
The proliferation of electric vehicles is creating new product opportunities
Manufacturers face rising foreign competition from low-cost countries
Companies are relocating production to lower-cost regions like Mexico

market_segmentation.segment_description: SUVs, CUVs and pickup trucks are extremely popular in the United States, driving this market's expansion.
Subcompact, compact, small and midsize cars, like sedans and hatchbacks, remain popular options for most consumers. These vehicles often have lower starting prices than SUVs.
Heavy trucks and buses require much larger and more powerful steering and suspension systems than consumer vehicles.

products_and_services.product_description: Steering systems consist of wheels, columns and gearboxes. Columns connect the when to the mechanism while a gearbox connects the pinion to the rack and helps control steering sensitivity. In general, steering systems generate a stable portion of revenue.

A suspension system consists of a series of springs, shock absorbers, struts and other parts that connect a motor vehicle to its wheels. The primary purpose of the suspension system is to improve ride quality. These systems absorb energy and reduce spring oscillations.

Companies produce a wide range of supplementary parts, like axles and ball joints, that assist in suspension and steering manufacturing. Companies also create replacement parts for a wide range of aftermarkets. These parts collectively generate the largest portion of revenue but separately account for smaller portions of revenue.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Operate in a location close to key markets
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Most companies operate near automakers to forge relations, reduce transportation costs and take advantage of existing manufacturing and automotive industry infrastructure.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Operate in a location close to key suppliers
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Most companies locate near key suppliers to reduce supply volatility and reduce costs. This strategy helps automobile steering and suspension manufacturers improve efficiency.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Low labor and transportation costs draw manufacturers abroad
international_trade_points.trade_description: Foreign steering and suspension manufacturers have developed a strong position in domestic markets. These parts are light, making transportation over long distances simple and inexpensive.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Companies have faced climbing import penetration
international_trade_points.trade_description: The dollar's appreciation, alongside increasing globalization, has created a path for inexpensive exports to overwhelm domestic automobile steering and suspension manufacturers. Even so, many domestic companies have close connections with leading automakers, securing positions in the supply chain.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The dollar's appreciation has diminished export markets
international_trade_points.trade_description: The trade-weighted index (TWI) has appreciated throughout most of the current period, making domestic goods relatively more expensive in foreign markets and severely limiting export opportunities.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Supply chains contracted during the pandemic
international_trade_points.trade_description: The pandemic led to widespread business closures, plummeting consumer sentiment and severely weakened trade markets. Severe supply chain disruptions limited total trade volumes significantly during the period.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region is highly populated with a growing percentage of downstream automobile and truck manufacturers, contributing to higher demand for automobile steering and suspension manufacturers. The region's high population also gives manufacturers a larger labor and consumer base than other regions. The region's proximity to Mexico also makes it a prime trading target.

The Great Lakes region is home to the second-largest concentration of steering and suspension manufacturing facilities. This region has historically been home to the bulk of United States automobile production. This region also provides easy access to Canada, especially Ontario, through major trade routes, like the Detroit-Windsor Tunnel. Companies take advantage of low trade barriers and proximity to sell to Canadian manufacturers.

The West region is home to a large percentage of the United States' population and many research institutions. This demographic provides manufacturers with a skilled labor force. The West provides easy access to Mexico, the most significant export destination and Asia. Many of the most popular automobile manufacturers in the United States, including Toyota and Honda, are based in Japan or South Korea.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Manufacturers require skilled labor to design, test and manufacture steering and suspension equipment, especially since designs must meet federal safety standards and strict buyer expectations.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Automobile steering and suspension manufacturers must adhere to strict safety and environmental regulations; products require extensive testing for NHTSA approval.

Automobile steering and suspension manufacturers need specialized equipment, tools, skilled labor and facilities to achieve economies of scale. Companies must also make significant investments in research and development.

basis_points.basis_description: The automobile steering and suspension manufacturing industry is highly competitive; companies offering innovative, lightweight products for lower costs will gain a competitive advantage.

concentration_points.concentration_title: International powerhouses have strong positions in US markets
concentration_points.concentration_description: Foreign-owned auto steering and suspension manufacturers, like Robert Bosch, have major operations in the United States. Many vertically integrated automakers, like Hyundai, also have establishments in the United States.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Leading manufacturers often leverage economies of scale to undercut domestic and foreign competitors.
concentration_points.concentration_description: This scale enables larger producers to secure lucrative contracts with automakers, expand operations and consolidate more easily than competitors.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Small manufacturers control the majority of the industry
concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry is primarily composed of smaller manufacturers that often act as sub-contractors, producing parts for sale to larger manufacturers. The prevalence of smaller manufacturers tends to lessen the concentration in the industry.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Manufacturers have faced high purchasing costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Automobile suspension and steering manufacturers rely on raw material inputs, including steel, aluminum, rubber and other durable alloys. Companies also need rubbers and plastics for final products. Manufacturers faced severe supply chain disruptions following the pandemic and the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Higher costs heavily diminished returns for most manufacturers; even so, successful manufacturers were able to pass added costs onto buyers, limiting supply chain volatility.

Manufacturers require skilled labor to design, test and manufacture steering and suspension equipment, especially since designs must meet federal safety standards and strict buyer expectations. Even so, companies have continued to automate production tasks to reduce their reliance on low-wage labor. Computer-aided design (CAD) systems have also enabled skilled workers to streamline design and development tasks.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Manufacturers have faced major input price volatility, contributing to a massive profit decline in 2021. Similarly, downstream auto and truck manufacturers exert significant pricing power over the automotive parts industries.

Similarly, domestic producers have faced mounting pressure from foreign producers in low-cost regions, like China and Mexico. These competitors have undercut domestic manufacturers, leading to lower prices and smaller returns.

FAQs.question: What are the key financial benchmarks and ratios for the automobile steering and suspension manufacturing industry?
FAQs.answer:
The key financial benchmarks and ratios include:
- Profit margin: 2.7% (lower than industry average)
- Average wage: $64,729 (lower than industry average)  
- Largest cost: Purchases at 67.2% of revenue
- EBIT/Revenue ratios ranging from 5.5% to 6.6% over the last 10 years
- Leverage ratio ranging from 11.1 to 37.0 over the last 5 years
- Return on net worth ranging from 4.8% to 15.2% over the last 10 years
- Interest coverage ratio around 300 over the last 3 years
- Current ratio around 1.6-1.7 over the last 3 years
- Quick ratio around 1.1-1.2 over the last 3 years

FAQs.question: What are the key trends impacting costs for this industry?
FAQs.answer:
The key trends impacting costs include:
- Manufacturers have faced high purchasing costs for raw materials like steel, aluminum, rubber and other inputs due to supply chain disruptions following the pandemic and Russia-Ukraine war. 
- Companies need skilled labor for design, testing and manufacturing to meet safety standards, though they are automating production tasks.
- The industry has endured volatile profits due to input price volatility, pricing pressure from downstream auto manufacturers, and competition from low-cost foreign producers.
